{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3143286,"name":"Gabor Szita","username":"gszita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-10T19:26:48.664Z","cooked":"

We’re designing an arm for our robot and wondering whether the PID should adjust the current or the voltage of the motor. Our motor supports setting both the current and the voltage.

Are there any benefits of one over the other? I was thinking setting the current is more accurate, because current is proportional to torque, but voltage isn’t necessarily. However, I didn’t see PID used with current as often as PID used with voltage.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-10T19:26:48.664Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2049,"reads":425,"readers_count":424,"score":10345.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Gabor Szita","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56947,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3143288,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-10T19:29:52.809Z","cooked":"

PID would generally use position or velocity as its feedback variable, and use that calculation to set motor output (generally voltage or fractional/percentage values).

What motor/controller are you using?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-10T19:30:14.465Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":417,"readers_count":416,"score":108.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/2","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143299,"name":"Noah Stricker","username":"tecnicraze","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tecnicraze/{size}/235517_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-10T19:42:09.335Z","cooked":"

Do voltage or duty cycle.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-10T19:42:09.335Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":393,"readers_count":392,"score":108.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Noah Stricker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54366,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alum"},"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/3","custom_user_title":"Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143321,"name":"Drakxii","username":"Drakxii","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-10T20:13:25.583Z","cooked":"

You set voltage, you limit current.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-10T20:13:25.583Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":387,"readers_count":386,"score":117.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Drakxii","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23134,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI "},"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/4","custom_user_title":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143456,"name":"Gabor Szita","username":"gszita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:02:32.972Z","cooked":"

I’m using falcon 500. The Phoenix Pro software for it supports the TorqueCurrentFOC control method, which we can use to set the current.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:02:32.972Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":347,"readers_count":346,"score":109.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Gabor Szita","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56947,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143463,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:09:25.940Z","cooked":"

The torque control itself is performed via PID. I would not use it unless you had a particular reason to want constant force.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:09:25.940Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":325,"readers_count":324,"score":100.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56947,"username":"gszita","name":"Gabor Szita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/6","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143476,"name":"Gabor Szita","username":"gszita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:25:38.869Z","cooked":"

The reason I want constant force is that the feedforward outputs torque, so adjusting the current is a better way to make sure that the torque applied on the motor is really the torque we want.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:25:38.869Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":311,"readers_count":310,"score":97.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Gabor Szita","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56947,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143481,"name":"Gabor Szita","username":"gszita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:28:07.611Z","cooked":"

I know that by setting voltage I limit current, but if I set voltage the current the motor uses can change depending on the load of the motor. This results the torque being different if the load on the motor is different.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:28:07.611Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":297,"readers_count":296,"score":69.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Gabor Szita","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":23134,"username":"Drakxii","name":"Drakxii","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/4da419/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56947,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143482,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:28:11.062Z","cooked":"

How do you intend to account for motor EMF while in torque mode?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:28:11.062Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":275,"readers_count":274,"score":85.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56947,"username":"gszita","name":"Gabor Szita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/9","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143484,"name":"Gabor Szita","username":"gszita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:31:25.995Z","cooked":"

That is the good thing about being TorqueCurrentFOC mode (as far as I understand) - I don’t have to account for back emf because torque is always proportional to current.

If I set the current and the back emf changes, the voltage consumed by the motor may change, but current will remain constant and therefore torque will also remain constant.

However, if I set the voltage and the back emf changes, the current consumed by the motor will change and therefore the torque will also change.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:31:25.995Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":273,"readers_count":272,"score":94.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Gabor Szita","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56947,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143489,"name":"Gabor Szita","username":"gszita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:33:28.232Z","cooked":"

Everyone has been saying that I should set the voltage, not the current, but does anyone has a specific reason why? The advantage of setting current is that torque can be better controlled. But what benefits does setting voltage offer?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:33:28.232Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":65.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Gabor Szita","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56947,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143492,"name":"Battery Nerd - FRC #4561","username":"sdtrent","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/9de053/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:42:17.926Z","cooked":"

General rule of thumb is you use voltage control PID for motor speed (shooter flywheel, intake roller, etc), and use current control PID when you want to set the maximum torque or force on a motor, to prevent motor or fixture damage when a motor moves to a hard stop), or to manage max current draw (i.e. reduce peak motor current to prevent radio brownout if battery voltage drops during a match). You can also limit drive motor current by setting lower maximum acceleration when using voltage PID.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:43:48.340Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":98.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Battery Nerd - FRC #4561","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56947,"username":"gszita","name":"Gabor Szita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54265,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Problem Solver"},"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/12","custom_user_title":"Problem Solver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143498,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:52:16.864Z","cooked":"
gszita:

Everyone has been saying that I should set the voltage, not the current, but does anyone has a specific reason why?

Because current control itself works by setting the voltage (via duty cycle). You can only fundamentally directly control voltage. Cascading the controller architecture through current control does not make sense in most dynamic situations.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:52:27.601Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":233,"readers_count":232,"score":96.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56947,"username":"gszita","name":"Gabor Szita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/13","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143499,"name":"Gabor Szita","username":"gszita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:52:50.423Z","cooked":"

Thank you for your answer, this is a very detailed explanation. In our case, with the arm, the load on the motor changes a lot depending on the arm’s position. Setting an accurate torque is far more important for us than controlling the speed, as we want to move the arm to a specific position as precisely as possible. Applying the correct torque to move the arm in its position is important, so do you think it would be better for us to use current control PID?

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:52:50.423Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":225,"readers_count":224,"score":75.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Gabor Szita","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54265,"username":"sdtrent","name":"Battery Nerd - FRC #4561","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/9de053/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56947,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143501,"name":"Gabor Szita","username":"gszita","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/9fc348/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T01:55:56.344Z","cooked":"

Why do you say it does not make sense? We tested how well it can adjust the torque using the TorqueCurrentFOC control mode and got a very strong linear correlation between the set current and the real torque it applied (0.976 R^2). This showed us that by setting the current we can very accurately control the torque, which wouldn’t be possible with setting the voltage.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2023-02-11T01:56:46.488Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":210,"readers_count":209,"score":82.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426370,"topic_slug":"should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor","display_username":"Gabor Szita","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56947,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/should-pid-set-the-current-or-voltage-of-a-motor/426370/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3143507,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-11T02:03:31.649Z","cooked":"

I think you have a fundamental misunderstanding of how current control works on the motor controller.

The motor controller fundamentally works by controlling duty cycle, which is proportional to voltage. Any control logic you run will work by controlling voltage. Current control uses a PID loop to track a reference current by controlling the voltage. Placing a current controller as the last step in your control stack is not going to magically give you better performance, and cascaded loops are often slower/less-stable than flat ones.

Thank you for your explanation, that makes sense. So how do you suggest I control the torque accurately on the motor by setting the voltage? I understand that the cascade loop will be less stable, but then how would I be able to control the torque as accurately as in the case of the TorqueCurrentFOC control mode?

If I follow what I have read recently on arm control, you likely want to use position PID, with some feedforward to help correct for gravity. There are a bunch of moving parts, but take them one at a time, and it is not as complicated as it seems. I would suggest limiting the peak current for the joint motors, but we are reaching the limits of my current knowledge for implementation. Ask me again in a week!

The concept is trapezoidal trapezoidal position control, which would work on it’s own mostly, but the each joint is controlled separately, and the response of the joint to changes in motor power will vary significantly as the orientation with respect to gravity changes. Properly tuned, this alone is likely to be “close enough”. But adding some feedforward by modeling the response of the arm can help improve the response. I think of it (rightly or wrongly) as changing the tuning of the PID as the arm changes position.

The reference below could help you get started.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Trapezoidal Motion Profiles in WPILib

While feedforward and feedback control offer convenient ways to achieve a given setpoint, we are often still faced with the problem of generating setpoints for our mechanisms. While the naive appro...

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Feedforward Control in WPILib

You may have used feedback control (such as PID) for reference tracking (making a system’s output follow a desired reference signal). While this is effective, it’s a reactionary measure; the system...

There are some great build logs being shared this season. Do some searching to find something that seems close to what your team is using, that you can follow. Think simple, low performance, not highlights from last season’s Einstein rounds.

Someone pointed this one out to me yesterday.

Team 3467 2023 Build Blog FRC Open Alliance

[Team 3467 2023 Prototype Arm Testing #1] [Team 3467 2023 Prototype Arm Testing #2] The above videos show the silver alpha robot in its final form, running with its pneumatic wrist, “beta” version of the arm control software, and “spinny no pinchy” claw (see above). When we…

Good luck!

This was a very good answer, I really appreciate your help. I also planned on using trapezoidal position control with feedforward accounting for gravity. Your answer is really helpful in figuring out the arm control. I marked it as the solution.

One small thing:
However, as @Oblarg pointed out, the TorqueCurrentFOC control mode attempts to track a reference current by controlling the voltage, which would lead to cascaded loops, which he says are less stable than flat ones. Do you think this would impact the control?

gszita:

. In our case, with the arm, the load on the motor changes a lot depending on the arm’s position. Setting an accurate torque is far more important for us than controlling the speed, as we want to move the arm to a specific position as precisely as possible

Based on your team’s other thread, your arm is very over powered, and you are probably very much overthinking this. With needing less then 1 volt to hold the arm at 90 degrees, I would just use a simple voltage PID, because the gravity feed forward term would be so small as to be negligible.

Double jointed arm physics: calculated voltage way too small? Programming
We’re planning on using an arm for our robot and we decided to try using Team 971’s feed forward code for the arm from 2013. This is the link for their python script that calculates the feed forward for the arm, but I created a shortened gist that removes the unnecessary parts of their code. The code works so far to calculate the torque to lift the arm. The calculated torque is 2.5 Nm, which is reasonable to lift the arm. However, when it converts the torque to voltage, I get 0.064 V as the vol…
